content.p: RMS has responded to the new DotGNU Manifesto draft with the words "It looks good to me".

a.h2: Apr 07-04-2003: Installer for MS Windows System available for download

content.p:
Bob Johnson has compiled DotGNU Portable.NET and TREECC for the Microsoft Windows system and created nice "installer" packages. Thanks, Bob! You can download the packages here:
PNET-0-5-4-Setup.zip and
TREECC-0.2-4-Setup.zip.

a.h2: Apr 04-04-2003: Discussion of W3C Patents Policy

content.p: A thoughtful discussion of W3C's new proposed Patents Policy, and why it is unacceptable from DotGNU's perspective, is unfolding at kuro5hin.org following an opinion piece posted by nb aka bizcoach.

Version 0.1.4 of DGEE, the DotGNU Execution Environment has been released. There is now full XML-RPC support, multiple VM support, multiple webservice language support, auto-generation of client XML-RPC code from assembly, and better memory management. An installation helper "dgeediagnose" is available for sorting out ipc resource issues.

DotGNU Portable.Net 0.5.4 has been released. Pnetlib 0.5.4 and TreeCC 0.2.4 have been released along with it. The high points are the beginnings of support for Generic IL and Reflection.Emit, with lots of little bug fixes here and there. Read more
here or go get it from here.

The Portable.NET project, which is central for DotGNU's efforts for compatibility with Microsoft's .NET, now has a firm
release schedule. Full support for ECMA standards 334 and 335 is epected by the end of June 2003.

DotGNU now has a collaborative webpage at wiki.dotgnu.org and is building a collection of information related to dotgnu and its subprojects. Adam Ballai has been central to this development and has set this up . So everyone is invited to chip in and go wiki.

The DotGNU Portable.net base tools now have support for Generic IL. Portable.NET is the first Free Software implementation of the CLI to release real support for Generic IL. It includes the assembler and disassembler for now. The compiler is being worked upon to support generic C# in the near future. Read all about what's done and what's not in
this mail .

DotGNU Portable.Net 0.5.2 has been released. Pnetlib 0.5.2 and TreeCC 0.2.2 have been released along with it. This release has been a quantum jump in portability with platforms as varied as x86,IA-64,S390,arm,PA-RISC etc being supported. Read about the rest of the new whistles and bells
here or go get it from here.

a.h2: Jan 27-01-2003: The RSS Feed is on !

content.p: The Dotgnu website team have decided that RSS is the way to go and true to our webservice initiatives we now have a cool RSS feed. Syndicate !

The linux conference went well and there is a significant amount of interest about the dotgnu project. The Portable.net presentation was well received and Rhys Weatherly is pretty satisfied with the level of interest. See him in the crowd in this
picture.

A paper about ``The Design of the Portable.NET Interpreter'' is being presented by Rhys Weatherly at the Linux Conference 2003, Australia. The paper will discuss the various levels of optimisations that are selected platform-wise to make the Portable.net interpreter faster and yet still remain truly portable. Read the entire paper in PDF
here.

Rhys Weatherly has brought out a good demo of Portable.net with a Mahjong game with Qt#. It works with the
Portable.net 0.5.0
release and the Qt# 0.6. Get the sources from
mahjong-0.0.1.tar.gz or see a screenshot at
Qt# website . Play on !

The DotGNU meetathon III has been scheduled to start today on 1000 UTC on irc.freenode.net#dotgnu . The meeting will discuss latest releases, portability and the general future of dotgnu. Read the official announcement here.

The DotGNU Portable.net and DotGNU DGEE are coming up with releases today. The Portable.net is having a milestone release of 0.5.0 . Read all about the Portable.net release
here . The new release has touched the half million line mark, read the exact figures
here . We'll be announcing the binary packages soon.

The DotGNU developer community has worked out a developers directory for identifying the major developers and their roles in dotgnu. The directory has been maintained in DotGNU People page. The list has been collected by request on the mailing lists and includes other details like email and irc nicks.

a.h2: Jan 05-01-2003: DGEE Demo up and running

content.p:
The Dotgnu Webservice container , otherwise known as the Dotgnu execution environment (DGEE) has reached usable levels. Chris Smith has hacked up this server which does not run inside Apache , but adopts the strategy other AppServers like Tomcat has been using. The C# webservice system is functional and uses Apache and Goldwater as the network and execution containers respectively. The system is self documenting and includes introspection into the webservices. It currently supports only XmlRpc and is only a pre-release. An initial demonstration was put up by Adam Ballai
here. Use the same URI for firing up XMLRPC requests . Also read more about DGEE
here.

Dotgnu welcomes the new year with hopes of moving up to becoming a major force in the world of free webservices. We've prepared a summary of the last year's progress, which I should say has been meteoric. We've voted Rhys Weatherly as the Developer of the Year for his nearly quarter million lines of code for the second year as well !. And here's the
This Year In Dotgnu.

The DotGNU Portable.Net has made quite a significant step towards usability in this year. The DotGNU Forum project which focusses on collaborative development over the internet is slowly gaining momentum as well. Read the full Pnet and Forum status reports for more details.

The Portable.Net platform now works on Win32 without any dependencies on the Cygwin wrappers. The build system uses the Minimal Gnu For Win32 or Mingw32 libraries to achieve this. Read the full announcement here.

The Qt# project has managed to compile its libraries and run the sample programs included with Qt# on Portable.Net. Excluding the Xml based bindings generator program , the rest of Qt# compile and run with ease on Portable.Net. The screenshots have been put up for a peek at Gui programming with Portable.net. Take a look at mandelbrot and scribblewindow.
Marios D Santana , has put out a preview of the development edition of MACS (Modular Access Control System) . The demo can be accessed from dexter . And the main MACS page is here .
Rhys explains what has been done in the past week in DotGNU Portable.Net . The new contributers , latest fixes and some other information compacted into a single mail. Read the detailed report here.

DotGNU Portable.Net 0.4.8 has been released. Pnetlib 0.4.8 and Treecc 0.1.8 have been released along with it. The big news for this release is that pnetlib now builds cleanly with pnet and works just fine with ilrun. We are finally 100% buildable from freesoftware . Read the rest of the new things in this announcement. Release tarballs for these are available :
pnet-0.4.8.tar.gz ,
pnetlib-0.4.8.tar.gz , and
treecc-0.1.8.tar.gz .

Chris Smith has brought out a nice specification for the DGEE core module communication. The good thing about this is that it is not tied down to XML or any encoding format, but allows arbitary data chunks such as XML, C# byte code, HTML form post data etc to be packaged together and sent as a single message between the internal components of the VRS/SEE core DGEE.
Read the full specification here. And get a proof of concept implementation in C here.

As a tail-ender to the IRC weekly meeting held on 16th a brief summary of development targets was made. The imminent release of Portable.Net 0.4.8 and 0.5.0 has prompted a re-evaluation. The TODO list for 0.5.0 and 0.4.8 has been posted to list . Read the full announcement here.
content.h2: Nov 9-11-2002: Initial import of Forum code
content.p: The first code of the DotGNU Forum System (Forum) has been imported into CVS. Currently features a Jabber-RPC server and database access code. Visit the Savannah project page here

DotGNU Portable.Net 0.4.6 has been released. Pnetlib 0.3.0 and Treecc 0.1.6 have been released along with it. Read all about what's new in 0.4.6, here. A release tarball of these are available at
http://www.southern-storm.com.au/download/pnet-0.4.6.tar.gz ,
http://www.southern-storm.com.au/download/pnetlib-0.3.0.tar.gz , and
http://www.southern-storm.com.au/download/treecc-0.1.6.tar.gz . For instructions to install , read the INSTALL included. Unfortunately we are having problems with our debian repository , please bear with us.

Thanks to the efforts of Peter Minten (silvernerd) , we now have a Ruby generator for treecc . Treecc is a tool that simplifies construction, manipulation and traversal of Abstract Syntax Trees . It was developed for building the Portable.Net compiler tools . See announcement here.
The entire pnetlib can now be compiled with cscc, and the resulting .dlls are totally verifiable. The .dlls have been used to run a sample HTTP server and a few GUI programs from Xsharp.

With the application of a
small patch to pnetlib (it changes only 5 lines), cscc can compile all of pnetlib. This means pnetlib hackers can directly test their modifications.

The Agenda for the weekly IRC meeting has been announced
here.
It includes support for Floating point support, PMCodeGen implementation, new language plugins for cscc and the type masking bug in cscc and other issues.

Charles Schuller (Kyeran) has provided us with a
daily build
of Portable.Net libraries. A
mirror of these as well as tarballs of CVS HEAD source has been provided by Stephen Compall (S11001001).

a.h2: Oct 19-10-2002: IRC Meeting with Parrot Developers

content.p:
The IRC meeting to discuss adding Parrot to the bytecodes supported by Portable.Net was a great success. The Parrot designer was here to discuss the details of generating Parrot from C#. Read all about it
here.

The Agenda for the weekly IRC meeting has been announced
here.
It includes support for Parrot , Using Treecc for wrapping gcc and other issues.

The DotGNU project is undergoing a restructuring due to the reduced threat of Microsoft's .NET deployment plan. The plans for a new and improved version of DotGNU can be found here.
here. The focus shift is from total .NET compatibility to a more useful and creative applications of DotGNU technologies.

To speed up the compiler development , Peter Minten, Gopal.V and Andrew Mitchell have formed the Weekend Warriors. This is a group of part time developers who devote their weekends to hacking pnet. This is responsible for the flurry of activity which happens on every weekend. The group proposes to take part of the compiler development in the following announcement.:
Weekend Warriors

As is customary, DotGNU will be having a Meet-a-thon this quarter as well. This is an event to take stock of the last quarter for the DotGNU developers, and an excellent oppurtunity for newcomers to familiarize themselves with the project. See the proposal for
this

a.h2: Oct 02-10-2002: Java Bytecode Output for Portable.Net

content.p:
Sylvain Pasche has fixed up the Portable.Net assembler to generate the correct java bytecode. Now the C# compiler sports a nice JVM output backend. The results become really interesting when the whole pnetlib can be compiled into JVM code. Read full details
here.
